explanation: The report is correct. OS_strnlen is implemented as: const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen); which makes memchr read up to maxlen bytes starting at s. In OS_TranslatePath the call OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN) passes a fixed maxlen but there is no guarantee that the object pointed to by VirtualPath actually has OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes accessible. If the NUL is not found within the first maxlen bytes and the buffer backing VirtualPath is smaller than maxlen (for example a shorter allocation or placed at the end of an allocation), memchr will access bytes beyond the object boundary. That is exactly the kind of out‑of‑bounds access MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 forbids. Note: the other calls that pass sizeof(filesys->... ) are safe, because sizeof gives the actual object size. Remedies include changing the API to accept an object size, ensuring callers guarantee an object of at least maxlen bytes, or reworking the implementation to avoid calling memchr with a length that might exceed the underlying object size.
